questions.text: An otherwise healthy 10-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of progressively enlarging breasts bilaterally for the past 4 days. The parents report that they have sometimes noticed a discharge of small quantities of a white liquid from the left breast since yesterday. During pregnancy, the mother was diagnosed with hypothyroidism and was treated with L-thyroxine. The patient's maternal grandmother died of breast cancer. The patient currently weighs 3100-g (6.8-lb) and is 51 cm (20 in) in length. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows symmetrically enlarged, nontender breasts, with bilaterally inverted nipples. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of serum estrogen and testosterone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Testosterone supplementation is indicated in cases of hypogonadism, which can also present with gynecomastia, but it is typically diagnosed in adolescents with delayed puberty onset or in adult men with decreased libido, hot flashes, and infertility.

B) CORRECT:

Neonatal gynecomastia is a common condition that occurs when maternal estrogen in the neonate's circulation stimulates glandular proliferation. This condition typically manifests with bilateral breast enlargement irrespective of biological sex. Some newborns may also present with a milky discharge (galactorrhea), which occurs when a decrease in the levels of maternal estrogen in the neonate's circulation stimulates the release of prolactin in the pituitary gland. Both gynecomastia and galactorrhea usually resolve spontaneously within a few weeks or months and do not require treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Breast biopsy is only indicated in suspected pathological gynecomastia to identify the underlying cause, if physical examination, imaging, and laboratory studies are inconclusive. This patient has no features suggestive of pathologic gynecomastia, which include occurrence outside the neonatal or pubertal age range, rapid progression, enlargement > 4 cm (1.6 inches), persistence for ≥ 12 months, or onset after age 17.

D) INCORRECT:

Hormonal assays are only indicated in suspected pathological gynecomastia to identify the underlying cause and include early morning measurement of serum hCG, estradiol, testosterone, LH, and DHEA. This patient has no features suggestive of pathologic gynecomastia, which include occurrence outside the neonatal or pubertal age range, rapid progression, enlargement > 4 cm (1.6 inches), persistence for ≥ 12 months, or onset after age 17.

E) INCORRECT:

Measurement of TSH is indicated in suspected hyperthyroidism, which may cause gynecomastia, but usually only in adults. Newborn hyperthyroidism could result from maternal L-thyroxin therapy in rare cases. However, newborns with hyperthyroidism present with a goiter, tachycardia, irritability, diarrhea, and vomiting, none of which are present in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Chromosomal analysis is only indicated when the underlying cause of breast enlargement is thought to be due to a chromosomal aberration such as Klinefelter syndrome (47 XXY), which usually becomes apparent at the onset of puberty, making it unlikely in this newborn. In addition to gynecomastia, patients with Klinefelter syndrome have a eunuchoid growth pattern, and testicular hypoplasia.

G) INCORRECT:

Since mammography is difficult to interpret in children and adolescents due to their increased density of the breast, ultrasonography is the preferred imaging modality if a pathological breast mass is suspected in this age group. This patient has no features suggestive of pathologic gynecomastia, which include occurrence outside the neonatal or pubertal age range, rapid progression, enlargement > 4 cm (1.6 inches), persistence for ≥ 12 months, or onset after age 17.

H) INCORRECT:

Hormonal assays are only indicated in suspected pathological gynecomastia to identify the underlying cause and include early morning measurement of serum hCG, estradiol, testosterone, LH, and DHEA. This patient has no features suggestive of pathologic gynecomastia, which include occurrence outside the neonatal or pubertal age range, rapid progression, enlargement > 4 cm (1.6 inches), persistence for ≥ 12 months, or onset after age 17.

I) INCORRECT:

Oral dicloxacillin is indicated for outpatient treatment of newborns with mastitis, which is mostly due to Staphylococcus aureus. Fullterm infants < 2 months of age with well-developed breasts due to stimulating intrauterine estrogens are most likely to develop such an infection. While this patient presents with nontender, bilateral breast enlargement and milky discharge, mastitis in infants is usually unilateral and presents with swelling, erythema, warmth, tenderness, induration, axillary lymphadenopathy, possibly pustules or bullae, and purulent discharge.
questions.hint: This newborn's condition is due to the placental transfer of maternal estrogens.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because he is concerned about the amount of breast tissue he has recently developed. His wife has noticed that he has been irritable for the past month. He was recently treated for tinea capitis. In preparation for an upcoming bodybuilding competition, he has been eating a lot of chicken breast. He drinks 2 beers every day. He smokes marijuana 3–4 times a week but does not smoke cigarettes. He weighs 90 kg (198 lb) and is 175 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall; BMI is 30 kg/m2. Physical examination shows bilateral gynecomastia and small, firm testes. There is no hepatosplenomegaly or abdominal tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
60%


Platelet count
400,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

135 mEq/L


 Cl-

97 mEq/L


 K+

4.5 mEq/L


 HCO3-

25 mEq/L


 Glucose
100 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Side effect of tinea capitis treatment

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Several agents that can be used as systemic therapy for tinea capitis (e.g., fluconazole, ketoconazole, itraconazole) can cause gynecomastia due to decreased testosterone synthesis. However, none of these agents would explain this patient's increased irritability or decreased testicular size, which are symptoms of excess testosterone.

B) CORRECT:

Anabolic steroids are synthetic derivatives of testosterone and are sometimes used by athletes to induce muscle building, although the practice is generally discouraged in professional athletics. Testosterone is converted to estradiol via the aromatase enzyme, so increased levels of testosterone lead to increased levels of estrogen, which result in gynecomastia. Increased testosterone levels are also associated with increased aggressiveness and irritability, as well as secondary hypogonadism (due to negative feedback effect on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis) that leads to a reduction in testicular size.

C) INCORRECT:

Physiologic gynecomastia can occur with aging, but after early puberty, it typically does not appear again until around the age of 50. This patient is only 40 years old and is presenting with additional symptoms of decreased testicular size and increased irritability, which suggests another cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Cirrhosis can cause gynecomastia and testicular atrophy but typically manifests with additional signs of jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, and skin changes. The lack of these findings makes cirrhosis an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Obesity can result in pseudogynecomastia, which refers to fat deposition around the nipples that does not involve glandular proliferation. While this patient has an elevated BMI (30 kg/m2) that technically classifies him as obese, he is preparing for a bodybuilding competition and is likely heavier because of his amount of muscle mass rather than excess fatty tissue.

F) INCORRECT:

Erythropoietin is sometimes used by athletes to stimulate erythropoiesis, which increases the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood. Side effects include hypertension, polycythemia, and increased risk of myocardial infarction and stroke. While a history of erythropoietin use would explain this patient's high hematocrit level, it would not explain his gynecomastia, irritability, or small testes. Moreover, erythropoietin use is generally seen in athletes aiming to increase endurance rather than those seeking to build muscle mass.

G) INCORRECT:

Marijuana use can be associated with the development of gynecomastia and irritability during withdrawal. However, the testicular atrophy present in this patient is not explained by marijuana use. This patient's clinical features and laboratory findings are more consistent with a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a lump beneath his right nipple that he discovered 1 week ago while showering. He has allergic rhinitis treated with cetirizine. He is at the 65th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. Examination shows a mildly tender, firm, 2-cm subareolar mass in the right breast; there are no nipple or skin changes. The left breast shows no abnormalities. Sexual development is Tanner stage 3. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's breast lump?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Leydig cell tumor can affect pre-pubertal and pubertal children by causing overproduction of either testosterone or estrogen. Although estrogen overproduction can cause gynecomastia, an estrogen-secreting Leydig cell tumor would result in bilateral gynecomastia rather than the unilateral gynecomastia seen here. Additionally, testicular examination of this patient showed no abnormalities; a testicular tumor would typically present as a palpable testicular mass.

B) INCORRECT:

Several drugs are associated with gynecomastia, including ketoconazole, spironolactone, digoxin, flutamide, leuprolide, and H2 antagonists (e.g., cimetidine). This patient's only medication is cetirizine, an H1 antagonist that is not known to cause gynecomastia. Moreover, drug-induced gynecomastia most often manifests as bilateral, diffuse enlargement of the breast tissue rather than the small, unilateral, limited mass seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Invasive ductal carcinoma is a neoplastic process that occasionally appears in male breasts. It most commonly manifests in older males (> 40 years), who present with a unilateral breast mass, nipple discharge (often bloody), and in some cases overlying skin or nipple changes. This patient is very young and does not have skin changes or discharge, making ductal carcinoma very unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Kallmann syndrome is a very rare cause of gynecomastia in adolescent males. Affected males typically have negligible facial or body hair. Moreover, one of the classic hallmarks of this syndrome is anosmia, and the absence of this feature makes this diagnosis very unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Klinefelter syndrome can also present with gynecomastia in an adolescent male. However, in patients with Klinefelter syndrome, bilateral, generalized enlargement of the breasts is much more common than the unilateral development of a localized mass seen here. Additionally, adolescents suffering from this syndrome are classically very tall and thin and present with lack of body and facial hair as well as testicular atrophy; this patient's height and weight are average for his age and he has normal testes.
Image Description:

Testicular hypoplasia and bilateral gynecomastia are characteristic features of Klinefelter syndrome.

F) CORRECT:

Puberty is associated with a variety of physical changes. Normal pubertal changes in males include growth spurts, increased testicular volume, penile enlargement, development of breast tissue (e.g., gynecomastia), the appearance of genital and axillary hair, and deepening of the voice. Pubertal gynecomastia is common (affecting up to 50% of adolescent boys) and typically occurs in patients aged 10–14 years. Manifestations of gynecomastia include small, mobile, soft, nontender or minimally tender masses that may be unilateral or bilateral and typically recede within 18 months.
Image Description:

Male patient with bilateral gynecomastia

G) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia is usually caused by a pituitary adenoma. Although it can cause breast enlargement, gynecomastia would be bilateral and it would typically be associated with galactorrhea, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, a pituitary adenoma would likely inhibit secretion of gonadotropins, causing a delay in puberty. This patient's unilateral breast enlargement, absence of any signs of pituitary adenoma (bitemporal hemianopsia, headache), and normal pubertal development make this diagnosis unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is likely the result of a transient imbalance between estrogens and androgens.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-month history of intermittent breast tenderness. The patient says, “Some of the kids on my swimming team are making fun of me because it looks like I have breasts.” He has mild persistent asthma well controlled with inhaled albuterol as needed. He appears anxious. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Physical examination shows firm, mobile, mildly tender bilateral masses located beneath the nipple-areolar complex; the mass on the right is 1 cm in diameter, the mass on the left is 0.6 cm in diameter. Pubic hair development is Tanner stage 3. The remainder of the examination, including genitourinary examination, shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Core-needle biopsy is a minimally invasive tool used to diagnose suspicious breast masses seen on ultrasonography or mammography. This patient's firm, mobile, mildly tender breast masses are consistent with a benign process, for which a core-needle biopsy is not required.

B) INCORRECT:

Several drugs are associated with the development of gynecomastia, including ketoconazole, spironolactone, and H2-receptor antagonists (e.g., cimetidine). However, this patient's only medication is albuterol, a short-acting beta-2 agonist that is not known to cause gynecomastia.

C) INCORRECT:

Karyotype analysis is used to confirm the diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome, which can manifest with bilateral gynecomastia in an adolescent. However, most patients with Klinefelter syndrome also present with additional signs of hypoandrogenism such as eunuchoid growth pattern, reduced facial and body hair, and testicular atrophy, none of which are seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum TSH concentration is measured in patients with suspected hyperthyroidism, which can manifest with bilateral gynecomastia. However, individuals with hyperthyroidism typically present with weight loss, heat intolerance, cardiovascular features (e.g., tachycardia, palpitations), and a goiter, none of which is seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Scrotal ultrasound can be used to diagnose sex-cord stromal tumors (e.g., Leydig cell tumors), which can manifest with bilateral gynecomastia. However, patients with these tumors typically present with precocious puberty in childhood. Additionally, a testicular tumor commonly manifests with a palpable testicular mass, whereas this patient's pelvic examination showed no abnormalities.

F) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the brain is indicated in patients with a suspected pituitary mass, which can manifest with signs of hypogonadism (e.g., gynecomastia). Although the secondary hypogonadism and bilateral gynecomastia observed in this adolescent boy could result from a pituitary adenoma, he lacks other features of the disease, such as delayed puberty, loss of facial and body hair, testicular atrophy, and signs of pituitary mass effect (e.g., headaches, bitemporal hemianopsia).

G) CORRECT:

Puberty in boys usually begins at the age of 9–14 years and is associated with a variety of physiological changes, including testicular volume increase, penile enlargement, changes in the growth of pubic and axillary hair, voice deepening, and a growth spurt. Breast tissue enlargement is another physiological change that occurs during puberty and typically manifests with small, firm, mobile breast masses that are either unilateral or bilateral. Pubertal gynecomastia is due to a more rapid increase in estrogen levels compared to testosterone and generally resolves by the age of 17–18 years when the adult ratio of estrogen/androgen is reached. Since this patient does not present with any concerning symptoms (e.g., overlying skin changes, nipple discharge, rapid enlargement of either mass, excessive pain), reassurance and observation are sufficient. If gynecomastia persists after 17–18 years of age, surgical removal of the breast glandular tissue can be considered.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is caused by an estrogen/androgen imbalance.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents with six months of symmetrical lumps beneath his nipples. He notes mild tenderness but no discharge or skin changes. He has no chronic illnesses or medications. Growth parameters are age-appropriate. Examination shows firm, disc-like swellings under both areolas without suspicious nodules.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Reassure that spontaneous resolution is likely
Initiate selective estrogen receptor modulator therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Physiologic gynecomastia in adolescents is a benign condition due to hormonal fluctuations during puberty, leading to an imbalance between estrogen and testosterone. This results in symmetrical, disc-like tissue beneath the nipples, often with mild tenderness. In the absence of concerning features such as discharge, rapid asymmetrical growth, or skin changes, reassurance is appropriate. The condition typically resolves spontaneously within months to a few years, making extensive workup or intervention unnecessary.

Key learning point: Adolescent gynecomastia is common and usually resolves spontaneously; reassurance is the most appropriate advice.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is reserved for persistent gynecomastia causing significant distress or with concerning features. The patient's presentation is typical of pubertal gynecomastia, which usually resolves spontaneously, making surgery unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

A serum hormone panel is indicated when there are signs of endocrine disorders, such as asymmetric growth or systemic symptoms. In this case, the presentation is consistent with physiological pubertal gynecomastia, which is a common, self-limited condition. The absence of red flags makes hormonal evaluation unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) are not warranted for physiologic pubertal gynecomastia, which is a transient condition due to normal hormonal changes. SERMs carry risks of side effects and are inappropriate for a benign, self-limited process in adolescents.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to your clinic because he is concerned about recent development of breast tissue. His wife has noticed increased irritability over the past month. He was recently treated for tinea capitis. He is preparing for a bodybuilding competition and has been eating a lot of chicken breast. He smokes marijuana 3–4 times a week but does not smoke cigarettes. He weighs 90 kg and is 175 cm tall; BMI is 30. On examination, he has bilateral gynecomastia and small, firm testes. There is no hepatosplenomegaly or abdominal tenderness. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Side effect of tinea capitis treatment.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anabolic steroids are synthetic derivatives of testosterone and are sometimes used by athletes to induce muscle building, although the practice is generally discouraged in professional athletics. Testosterone is converted to estradiol via the aromatase enzyme, so increased levels of testosterone lead to increased levels of estrogen, which result in gynecomastia. Increased testosterone levels are also associated with increased aggressiveness and irritability, as well as secondary hypogonadism (due to negative feedback effect on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis) that leads to a reduction in testicular size.

Key learning point: Anabolic steroid use can cause gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, and increased irritability due to excess androgens and their conversion to estrogens with suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

B) INCORRECT:

Physiologic gynecomastia can occur with aging, but after early puberty, it typically does not appear again until around the age of 50. This patient is only 40 years old and is presenting with additional symptoms of decreased testicular size and increased irritability, which suggests another cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Several agents that can be used as systemic therapy for tinea capitis (e.g., fluconazole, ketoconazole, itraconazole) can cause gynecomastia due to decreased testosterone synthesis. However, none of these agents would explain this patient's increased irritability or decreased testicular size, which are symptoms of excess testosterone.

D) INCORRECT:

Obesity can result in pseudogynecomastia, which refers to fat deposition around the nipples that does not involve glandular proliferation. While this patient has an elevated BMI (30 kg/m2) that technically classifies him as obese, he is preparing for a bodybuilding competition and is likely heavier because of his amount of muscle mass rather than excess fatty tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Marijuana use can be associated with the development of gynecomastia and irritability during withdrawal. However, the testicular atrophy present in this patient is not explained by marijuana use. This patient's clinical features and laboratory findings are more consistent with a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 13-year-old boy comes to your clinic after noticing a lump beneath his right nipple 1 week ago while showering. He has allergic rhinitis and takes cetirizine. He is at the 65th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. On examination, there is a mildly tender, firm, 2-cm subareolar mass in the right breast without nipple or skin changes. The left breast is normal. Sexual development is Tanner stage 3. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for his breast lump?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Klinefelter syndrome can also present with gynecomastia in an adolescent male. However, in patients with Klinefelter syndrome, bilateral, generalized enlargement of the breasts is much more common than the unilateral development of a localized mass seen here. Additionally, adolescents suffering from this syndrome are classically very tall and thin and present with lack of body and facial hair as well as testicular atrophy; this patient's height and weight are average for his age and he has normal testes.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperprolactinemia is usually caused by a pituitary adenoma. Although it can cause breast enlargement, gynecomastia would be bilateral and it would typically be associated with galactorrhea, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, a pituitary adenoma would likely inhibit secretion of gonadotropins, causing a delay in puberty. This patient's unilateral breast enlargement, absence of any signs of pituitary adenoma (bitemporal hemianopsia, headache), and normal pubertal development make this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Several drugs are associated with gynecomastia, including ketoconazole, spironolactone, digoxin, flutamide, leuprolide, and H2 antagonists (e.g., cimetidine). This patient's only medication is cetirizine, an H1 antagonist that is not known to cause gynecomastia. Moreover, drug-induced gynecomastia most often manifests as bilateral, diffuse enlargement of the breast tissue rather than the small, unilateral, limited mass seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

A Leydig cell tumor can affect pre-pubertal and pubertal children by causing overproduction of either testosterone or estrogen. Although estrogen overproduction can cause gynecomastia, an estrogen-secreting Leydig cell tumor would result in bilateral gynecomastia rather than the unilateral gynecomastia seen here. Additionally, testicular examination of this patient showed no abnormalities; a testicular tumor would typically present as a palpable testicular mass.

E) CORRECT:

Puberty is associated with a variety of physical changes. Normal pubertal changes in males include growth spurts, increased testicular volume, penile enlargement, development of breast tissue (e.g., gynecomastia), the appearance of genital and axillary hair, and deepening of the voice. Pubertal gynecomastia is common (affecting up to 50% of adolescent boys) and typically occurs in patients aged 10–14 years. Manifestations of gynecomastia include small, mobile, soft, nontender or minimally tender masses that may be unilateral or bilateral and typically recede within 18 months.

Key learning point: Pubertal gynecomastia is a common, benign, and self-limited finding in adolescent boys, typically presenting as a small, tender, subareolar mass that often resolves within 18 months.
Image Description:

Male patient with bilateral gynecomastia
questions.hint: This patient's condition is likely the result of a transient imbalance between estrogens and androgens.
